content:
#29735 introduces a Preorder instance for Quotient s, characterized by the fact that the Quotient.lift of a monotone function is monotone. This probably looks weird, since it's not at all used in mathematics – except when the equivalence classes are order connected, in which case a linear order can descend to the quotient (this is sometimes called a "condensation", I believe). This is a necessary ingredient for #29687.

There's some prior (albeit disorganized) discussion on Zulip. The main questions seem to be two:

  • Is it ok to have such a general instance? On the one hand most quotients don't care for or even want this weird order instance; on the other most practical quotients are already behind aliases, so they won't even get this instance.
  • What API should exist for these instances? My PR is very minimal in that regard, though apparently there's a bunch of other ways to write down the definition for ≤.
Note that by the way #29687 uses this instance, I wouldn't really have any trouble with just making it a scoped instance or even a def.
